title: 111_hr6035
content: The "Foreign Oil Displacement Act of 2010" aims to reduce the US dependence on imported oil by promoting a synthetic fuels industry using domestic resources. Financial incentives are needed to encourage private investment in facilities for producing synthetic fuels or gas on a commercial scale. The "Foreign Oil Displacement Act of 2010" promotes a synthetic fuels industry using domestic resources. It includes a Carbonaceous Fuels Facility Credit under the Internal Revenue Code to incentivize private investment in facilities for producing synthetic fuels or gas on a commercial scale. The Carbonaceous Fuels Facility Credit allows for a 30% credit on qualified investments in carbonaceous fuels conversion facilities. Qualified investments include property placed in service by the taxpayer as part of the facility. The Carbonaceous Fuels Facility Credit provides a 30% credit for qualified investments in carbonaceous fuels conversion facilities, including property with a useful life of at least 3 years. There is a special rule for sale-leasebacks where the facility is treated as placed in service when used under the leaseback or lease agreement. The leaseback (or lease) mentioned in subparagraph (B) can be elected by the lessee and lessor of the property, with consent needed to revoke the election. Rules similar to those of subsections (c)(4) and (d) of section 46 apply for qualified progress expenditures. A carbonaceous fuels conversion facility is defined as a facility used to produce a qualified fuel. The term 'qualified fuel' is defined as per section 45K(c), with coal including peat and byproducts from coal preparation facilities containing fixed carbon. This section does not apply if other credits are allowed unless waived by the taxpayer. The credit can be assigned by the taxpayer. If a taxpayer elects, the credit determined under this section can be assigned to another person without inclusion in the assignee's gross income. This section applies to specific periods and defines 'qualified fuel' as per section 45K(c), including coal and its byproducts. The section applies to periods after enactment and before January 1, 2024, with rules similar to section 48(m). Special rules apply for the recapture of the investment tax credit for carbonaceous fuels conversion facilities under section 48E. The section applies to periods after enactment and before January 1, 2024, with rules similar to section 48(m). Special rules apply for the recapture of the investment tax credit for carbonaceous fuels conversion facilities under section 48E. Credit allowed under section 38 for all prior taxable years with respect to a carbonaceous fuels conversion facility multiplied by a fraction based on remaining depreciation years. The text discusses amendments to tax rules for qualified progress expenditures for carbonaceous fuels conversion facilities under section 48E and changes to section 50(a) and 49(a)(1) of the Code. The portion of the basis of any carbonaceous fuels conversion facility attributable to any qualified investment is defined by section 48E(b). A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart E of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after the enactment of this Act. Exemption from manufacturers excise tax on fuels is discussed in Section 4. The amendment to section 4083 of the Internal Revenue Code defines qualified carbonaceous fuel as fuel produced by a carbonaceous fuels conversion facility. This exemption applies to taxable fuel, gasoline, diesel fuel, and kerosene. The amendment made by this section defines the application period and effective date for the changes. It applies from the 91st day after enactment until December 31, 2023, with the amendment taking effect on the date of the Act's enactment.
